results.headline: Childhood Friends, Torn Apart by Ambitions
results.summary_short: “Mission Park,” directed by Bryan Anthony Ramirez, is about four childhood friends whose ambitions land them on opposite sides of the law.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mission Park

results.headline: A Surprise at the Door
results.summary_short: Joey Dedio is a bachelor who inherits his sister’s six (six!) children after an accident in Fro Rojas’s “Tio Papi.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tio Papi

results.headline: That’s One Devil of a Fixer-Upper
results.summary_short: In “Hell Baby,” an expectant couple move into a wreck of a place and soon need an exorcist or two.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hell Baby

results.headline: Where AIDS Steals Life by the Millions
results.summary_short: Dylan Mohan Gray’s “Fire in the Blood” centers on the millions of Africans with AIDS who have died because they could not afford lifesaving drugs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fire In The Blood

results.headline: Soldiers of Fortune Fighting Corporate Greed
results.summary_short: In Henry Saine’s dystopian “Bounty Killer,” the superstars hunt white-collar criminals.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bounty Killer

results.headline: In an Affair With a Student, Someone Learns Painful Lessons
results.summary_short: In Hannah Fidell’s debut feature, a young high school teacher has an affair with one of her teenage students.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Teacher

results.headline: Young Man Shows His True Colors
results.summary_short: In the comedy “American Milkshake,” Tyler Ross plays a white boy in mid-1990s who wishes he were black.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Milkshake

results.headline: Macroeconomics and the Little Guy
results.summary_short: “American Made Movie” pins the decline of the manufacturing sector on forces seemingly beyond anyone’s control and the hopes for reversing it on plucky individuals.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Made Movie

results.headline: A Valentine for One, a Mother’s Day Card for Another
results.summary_short: “Adore,” the first-English language film of the French director Anne Fontaine, has mothers finding lovers at the neighbor’s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adore

results.headline: Strangeness, Even for New York
results.summary_short: Survivors of a plane crash are dying in “36 Saints,” and two detectives try to stop the apparently supernatural forces behind the killings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 36 Saints

results.headline: A Look Behind What You Hear
results.summary_short: The documentary “La Maison de la Radio” explores the inner workings of Radio France.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Maison de la radio

results.headline: Gandhian Goodness Confronting Greed
results.summary_short: In “Satyagraha,” a movement arises over corruption and efforts to combat it in an Indian town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Satyagraha

results.headline: Wandering Souls, United in Rebellion
results.summary_short: “The Last Christeros” follows a band of 1930s rebels through the Mexican wilderness as they struggle with loneliness and fatigue.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Christeros

results.headline: Meet the Boys: A Mutual Lovefest
results.summary_short: Morgan Spurlock’s concert film about the British-Irish boy band One Direction features shirtless torsos and backstage performances and a taste of each performer’s persona.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Direction: This is Us

results.headline: A Jaded Boomerang Returns
results.summary_short: “The Lifeguard” centers on a young woman whose New York life goes off the tracks, so she moves back home to take up her old summer job.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lifeguard

results.headline: Sisters in Arms (and in Pricey Couture)
results.summary_short: “Tiny Times 2,” a sequel to a Chinese film about four high school best friends, vaults them into a cutthroat, consumerist career world in Shanghai.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tiny Times 2

results.headline: Want to See the Wife Again? Just Follow Directions
results.summary_short: In “Getaway,” a former professional racecar driver’s wife is kidnapped, and he is warned that he will never see her again unless he steals a vehicle and follows instructions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Getaway

results.headline: It’s Vacation Time, Grief Stalker
results.summary_short: “Dark Tourist” focuses on a fateful trip by a security guard (Michael Cudlitz) whose twisted hobby is visiting scenes of serial killings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Tourist

results.headline: Glass Ceilings Can Be Cutting
results.summary_short: Rachel McAdams and Noomi Rapace negotiate a dangerous office environment in Brian De Palma’s “Passion.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passion

results.headline: Mom Comes Home With a Stripper
results.summary_short: In the comedy “Afternoon Delight,” a discontented housewife in Los Angeles hires a stripper to be her son’s nanny.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Afternoon Delight
